benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{email} - Delete email from account

covered: Valid Deletion: Multiple successful-deletion scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC12, TC13, TC17, TC18) verify 204 responses and post-condition that the email no longer exists.
Non-Existent Resource: Scenarios for missing account and missing email (TC03, TC04, TC09) verify 404 handling and error messages.
Input Validation: Invalid accountId and invalid email formats are tested (TC05, TC06) producing 400 responses.
Required Headers: Missing required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC07) to validate header enforcement.
Optional Headers: Use of optional headers (X-Killbill-Reason, X-Killbill-Comment) is covered (TC02).
Authorization: Unauthorized/invalid token case is covered (TC10) returning 401.
Dependency / Server Errors: Service-unavailable / dependency failure is simulated (TC11) expecting 503.
Concurrency / Race Conditions: Concurrent delete requests are tested (TC15) expecting one 204 and subsequent 404s.
Security Input Validation: Injection/XSS in the email parameter is tested (TC16) expecting validation failure.
Edge Cases: Very long and minimal-length email addresses are covered (TC12, TC13).
Performance: Simple response-time check is included (TC14).
Resilience / Retry: Transient network failure + retry recovery is covered (TC19).
Backward compatibility / Regression: Regression and compatibility checks for uppercase and legacy clients are present (TC17, TC18).
gaps: Soft Delete Semantics: No tests verify whether deletion is soft (resource marked deleted but retrievable) vs hard delete (permanent removal) or verify audit/log persistence.

Exact Error Codes/Response Bodies: While many error scenarios exist, there is limited specification/tests for exact error body schema (fields, error codes) and consistent message contents beyond 'contains an error message'.
Authorization Granularity: Tests cover invalid token (401) but do not cover forbidden/insufficient-permission cases (403) or role-based access variations.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for rate limiting or behavior under high request rates (beyond TC15 concurrency focused on race condition).

Idempotency Semantics: There is no explicit test documenting idempotency expectations of repeated DELETE calls beyond concurrent-first-success behavior; not all repeated-call permutations are covered (e.g., sequential repeated calls expected responses).
Path Encoding / URL-encoding: No tests for URL-encoding edge cases in the email path segment (spaces, plus signs, reserved characters) except XSS case; percent-encoding behavior not verified.
Logging / Audit Headers Persistence: No tests verifying that X-Killbill-CreatedBy/Reason/Comment are persisted to audit logs or show up in change history.

Pagination / GET-related concerns: Although not directly relevant to DELETE, the standard guidelines include pagination/GET behaviour — there are no cross-checks that deletion affects downstream GET/listing endpoints or that empty-list responses behave correctly after deletes.
Cache Invalidation: No tests to verify that caches (ETag/Cache-Control) are invalidated or updated after deletion (i.e., stale GET responses).
Malformed URL / Path Traversal: No tests for path traversal attempts or malformed URLs beyond invalid formats.
recommendations: Add soft-delete verification tests: confirm whether deleted emails can be recovered, check 'deleted' flags, and validate audit trail entries (who/when/reason/comment).
Specify and assert exact error response schema and fields for each error scenario (HTTP status, error code, message key) to avoid ambiguous 'contains message' checks.
Include 403/permission tests: create scenarios where an authenticated user lacks permission to delete and expect 403 (forbidden).
Add rate-limiting and throttling tests: send many rapid requests and verify 429 or configured throttling behavior and graceful handling.
Expand idempotency tests: include sequential repeated DELETE requests (not concurrent) and assert consistent, documented responses (e.g., subsequent 404 or 204 depending on spec).
Add URL-encoding tests: verify deletion for emails containing '+', spaces, quoted/local-part characters, and ensure proper percent-encoding handling.
Verify cache invalidation and downstream GETs: after delete, perform GET/list calls to ensure the deleted email is absent and any caching headers/ETags behave correctly.
Add audit/log assertions: verify that X-Killbill-CreatedBy, Reason, and Comment are recorded in change history or logs where applicable.
Add malformed-path and path-traversal tests to ensure robust parsing and security of the path parameter.
Document test expectations for response time under higher loads and include SLA-oriented performance tests beyond a single 500ms check.
